text: does anyone know of any attempts to write a JSON parser in julia that doesn't allocate ?

elements.text: does anyone know of any attempts to write a JSON parser in julia that doesn't allocate ?

text: doesn't a parser allocate by definition? If you don't allocate, where do you store the stuff you've parsed?

elements.text: doesn't a parser allocate by definition? If you don't allocate, where do you store the stuff you've parsed?

text: you give it a schema or something and pass in a struct to populate

elements.text: you give it a schema or something and pass in a struct to populate

text: or it provides a non-allocating set of accessors that work on a raw byte array

elements.text: or it provides a non-allocating set of accessors that work on a raw byte array

text: those only work for pretty simple JSON. Any list with a variable number of items will force allocation (even if you work on the byte array. you still need to store a variable length list of start and end points).

elements.text: those only work for pretty simple JSON. Any list with a variable number of items will force allocation (even if you work on the byte array. you still need to store a variable length list of start and end points).

text: nevertheless its pretty common to already have some knowledge of the json structure

elements.text: nevertheless its pretty common to already have some knowledge of the json structure

text: in fact Ill bet it wouldnt be too hard to write something that generates a type that can efficiently represent a specific JSON message

elements.text: in fact Ill bet it wouldnt be too hard to write something that generates a type that can efficiently represent a specific JSON message

text: Have you seen JSON3.jl or LazyJSON.jl?

elements.text: Have you seen JSON3.jl or LazyJSON.jl?

text: lazy json that sounds like my kind of json

elements.text: lazy json that sounds like my kind of json

text: I think both support streaming to a file so you never need to contruct the objects (if that is what you mean by no allocation).

elements.text: I think both support streaming to a file so you never need to contruct the objects (if that is what you mean by no allocation).
